stem: The emergency department nurse is assessing four clients with adverse reactions to psychiatric medications. Based on the clinical data in the EHR, match each client's presentation with the most likely therapeutic class of the offending medication.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Client A: 50-year-old female with long-term schizophrenia. Noted repetitive, involuntary tongue thrusting and lip-smacking.
Client B: 32-year-old male. Reports 'worst headache of my life' after eating a charcuterie board with aged cheeses. BP is 210/118.
Client C: 45-year-old female. Reports sore throat and fever (102°F). She was recently started on a medication for treatment-resistant schizophrenia.
Client D: 24-year-old male. Exhibits tremors, hyperreflexia, and diaphoresis. He recently added an over-the-counter herbal supplement for depression.

rows.text: Client A: Involuntary tongue thrusting and lip-smacking
Client B: Hypertensive crisis after consuming aged cheese/tyramine
Client C: Severe agranulocytosis (low WBC) and sore throat

rationale.correct: Tardive dyskinesia (r1) is a common long-term side effect of typical antipsychotics. Hypertensive crisis from tyramine (r2) is the hallmark of MAOIs. Agranulocytosis (r3) is a life-threatening side effect specifically associated with the atypical antipsychotic clozapine, requiring frequent WBC monitoring. Serotonin syndrome (r4) occurs with SSRIs, especially when combined with other serotonergic agents (like St. John's Wort).
clinicalPearls: Any patient on clozapine with a sore throat or fever must have an immediate CBC with differential.
SSRI + St. John's Wort = Serotonin Syndrome (twitchy/hyperreflexic).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'Clozapine / Closes the bone marrow'. It is the primary one associated with severe neutropenia.

mnemonic.title: MAOI No-No Foods
mnemonic.expansion: PANAMA: P-Picked/Preserved, A-Aged Cheese, N-Nuts (some), A-Alcohol (Red wine), M-Meats (Salami/Pepperoni), A-Avocado (large amounts).
